paper_title: The influence of different synthetic solvents on photocatalytic activity of ZIF-8 for methanol production from CO2

catalyst.source: In this article, we investigate the effect of synthetic solvents on the surface characteristics of the zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) and its photocatalytic activities.
catalyst.context: In this article, we investigate the effect of synthetic solvents on the surface characteristics of the zeolitic imidazolate framework-8 (ZIF-8) and its photocatalytic activities.Different solvents (deionized (DI) water -ZIF-8 (W), methanol -ZIF-8(M), and a combination of ammonia and ethanol -ZIF-8(A)) were employed to prepare three ZIF-8 samples at room temperature.The fourth sample was obtained after 24 h immersion of ZIF-8(A) in methanol to evacuate pores which we named ZIF-8(AM).These four samples were characterized using XRD, FTIR, FESEM, BET, DRS, and AFM.BET and AFM measurements revealed that all ZIFs have a specific surface area above 1300 m 2 /g while their surface roughness or heterogeneity differs.In contrast to ZIF-8(AM), with the highest level of surface heterogeneity, ZIF-8(M) displayed a very smooth and homogeneous surface.We tested all as-made ZIF-8s for methanol production via CO 2 reduction under UV-vis light irradiation.The results indicate that ZIF-8(AM) produces a high amount of methanol (ca.500 mol.g - cat ) while ZIF-8(M) is almost inactive.These findings reveal that in addition to BET surface area, surface heterogeneity is a significant parameter on photocatalytic activity of ZIF-8.

catalyst.source: The influence of surface characteristics of ZIF-8 on its photocatalytic activity towards CO 2 reduction to methanol was investigated in this study.
catalyst.context: The influence of surface characteristics of ZIF-8 on its photocatalytic activity towards CO 2 reduction to methanol was investigated in this study.Four different ZIF-8 samples using different synthetic solvents were prepared at room temperature and then thoroughly analyzed by various techniques.BET confirmed that all samples contain great specific surface area while AFM images unveiled different surface heterogeneity for the samples.ZIF-8(AM), which was synthesized by ammonia and then immersed in methanol, indicated the highest level of heterogeneity.After that, ZIF-8(A) and ZIF-8(W) showed almost the same heterogeneity, slightly smoother than ZIF-8(AM).On the surface of ZIF-8 synthesized using methanol, no heterogeneity was observed.Eventually, all fresh samples were tested in the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 to methanol process.Moreover, the bandgap energy for all ZIF photocatalysts was calculated using Tauc Plot, indicating that ZIF-8(AM) and ZIF-8(W) correspond to the smallest and largest amount of E g , respectively.As a consequence, ZIF-8(AM), which demonstrated the most heterogeneous surface, highest surface area, and smallest E g , produced the highest amount of methanol equal to 523.4 mol.g -1 cat and afterward ZIF-8(A), ZIF-8(W), and ZIF-8(M) were ranked.The stability and reusability of the samples were studied by different analyses like XRD, FTIR, UV-vis, and GC.The obtained results confirmed the high stability of the prepared samples in the process of CO 2 reduction.These results clearly demonstrate the importance of the synthetic solvents on the ZIF- Fig. 8.The effect of recycling runs on the methanol production yield using fresh (First), and recovered samples (Second). light source.source: The evaluation of the photocatalytic activity of each catalyst was conducted in a batch reactor under UV-vis irradiation in the presence of water.
light source.context: All required chemicals for the synthesis of ZIF-8 including Zinc nitrate hexahydrate, 2-methylimidazole (Hmim), Ammonium hydroxide solution (25 wt in water), ethanol (99), and methanol (99) were supplied from Sigma-Aldrich and Merck and were used as received without further purification.Also, high purity CO 2 (ca.99.99) was provided by Toos Oxygen Corporation (Iran). Water-based ZIF-8 was prepared using the methods reported in the literature with some modifications 32,33.The synthesis begins with the addition of 1.7 g of zinc nitrate hexahydrate into 10 mL deionized water.The solution is stirred for 10 min.Then, the solution was slowly added in a linker emulsion containing 80 mL ethyl alcohol and 22.7 g Hmim and stirred for 15 min.When zinc nitrate solution was added to the Hmim solution slowly, the mixture color changed to milky white.The mixture was stirred for 15 min at room temperature and then kept aging for 7 days.The ZIF-8 precipitate was washed with deionized water several times and dried at 70 C for 12 h. Ammonia-based ZIF-8 was synthesized by the procedures presented in our previous works 34,35.A linker solution containing 1 g Hmim and 12 mL ethanol was added dropwise into zinc nitrate solution that was prepared by dispersion of 0.8 g zinc nitrate hexahydrate in 15 mL ammonium hydroxide 25.After the color of the mixture changed, the milky white solution stirred for 24 h at room temperature and then centrifuged with ethanol several times and dried at 70 C for 12 h. To prepare ZIF-8 (AM), 0.3 g of the as-synthesized ZIF-8 (A) were added into 30 mL methanol and stirred under reflux at 70 C for 24 h.White sediment was observed after centrifugation and drying at 70 C. To prepare methanol based ZIF-8, the linker solution containing 3.28 g Hmim and 100 mL methanol was added slowly into Zn 2 solution that provided by dissolving 2.97 g Zn(NO 3 ) 2 .6H 2 O in 100 mL methanol.The resulting milky white solution was kept 24 h under stirring at room temperature, and then it was washed with methanol several times and dried at 70 C for 12 h 36.A simple schematic for ZIF-8 samples prepared using different solvents is depicted in Scheme 1. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using Bruker D8-Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu-K ( 1.54178A ) radiation.The surface area, pore volume, and pore size distribution of the catalysts were determined from N 2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K using Micrometrics ASAP 2020 adsorption instrument.Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy was measured by an Avantes model Avaspec-2048-TEC equipped with AvaLamp DH-S Setup.Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy was recorded on a Thermo Nicolet Avatar 360 (U S A) at room temperature using compacted KBr pellets.By using the TESCAN electron microscope (Mira III, Czech Republic) FESEM images were taken, and then surface topography and roughness of catalysts were performed using ICON atomic force microscope (BRUKER, USA).Also, a 125 W mercury vapor lamp (OSRAM, Germany) was used as the excitation source for the study of photocatalysts wavelength in the range between 300 and 700 nm. The evaluation of the photocatalytic activity of each catalyst was conducted in a batch reactor under UV-vis irradiation in the presence of water.At first, to saturate the solution, high purity CO 2 was bubbled in a three-neck flask glass vessel containing 50 mL water at a constant flow rate for 30 min (Fig. S1).Afterward, 0.05 g of each sample of ZIF-8 photocatalyst were added to the saturated water, and the emulsion was stirred for 1 h under lamp irradiation. The final liquid product was first centrifuged to eliminate the catalysts from reaction media and then analyzed by a GC-FID Agilent JW DB-ALC column instrument (Santa Clara, CA, USA).No product formation was observed neither without photocatalyst nor light, and conversely, CH 3 OH was found and measured when there was the presence of light, photocatalyst and CO 2 .
